training_organizations.name: Alabama DHR – Child Welfare Training
training_organizations.description: The Alabama Department of Human Resources provides training for CPS staff, including pre-service preparation and ongoing professional development for child welfare workers (covering investigation procedures, case management, and family support practices).

training_organizations.name: National Children's Advocacy Center (NCAC)
training_organizations.description: A Huntsville-based nonprofit that serves as a national training center for child abuse professionals, providing specialized instruction in forensic interviewing and child abuse investigation techniques. NCAC regularly trains Alabama's law enforcement and CPS investigators on best practices for interviewing children and coordinating multi-disciplinary responses to abuse.

training_organizations.name: VOICES for Alabama’s Children
training_organizations.description: A statewide child advocacy nonprofit that works to improve Alabama’s child welfare policies and outcomes. It monitors the child protection system and advocates for reforms, service improvements, and resources to better protect children and support families.

perpetrator_relationships.relationship: Victim Was Child of Boyfriend or Girlfriend

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.TribalReport: Yes, Tribes directly accept reports and collaborate with state/local public child welfare agency
policies.DefAge_Specify: Under age 18 with variability under 18 and over 18
policies.DecentralScreen: Each county/region has own screening unit
policies.ReportAnonymous: General public (not mandated reporters) can remain anonymous
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical abuse, emotional maltreatment (mental injury), sexual abuse, trafficking (sexual exploitation), and punishment
policies.Def_Subtype_Other: Chemical endangerment includes exposure to a drug lab and illegal substances
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes inadequate clothing, inadequate food, inadequate shelter, medical neglect, failure to thrive, abandonment, failure to protect, failure to provide supervision, and mental abuse/neglect
policies.Penalty_OtherSpecify: Sentence of not more than 6 months imprisonment or a fine of not more than $500
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Photographs to document physical injuries or conditions of children, or neglectful conditions of child's home
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: Report to the district attorney's office and local law enforcement agency any report of child abuse or neglect
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Vulnerability of the child and potential risk of harm to child
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: Failure to provide adequate clothing/personal hygiene to the extent it poses a risk of serious harm to the child applies to children under age 12 and to those, regardless of age, who have a disability that prevents self-care; Child's age is under age 19 when person is in need of protective services and does not qualify for adult protective services
policies.DefHarm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Physical abuse and its subtypes of maltreatment include death, bodily injury, or impairment of physical condition; Neglect and its subtypes of maltreatment include impairment of mental or emotional condition and harmful environment or conditions (e.g., inadequate supervision, food, shelter, clothing, etc. which put children at risk of harm)
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For all categories of neglect, the perpetrator is a parent or primary caregiver; For medical neglect, the perpetrator is a parent and guardian; For abuse, the perpetrator is any person age 14 or older
policies.AltResp_Inelig_OtherSpecify: Any child abuse and neglect based on the definitions of state statutes and the Department
policies.ScreenReq_OtherCases_Specify: Reports must be reported to the District Attorney's office and the local law enforcement agency, according to the County Department's written working agreement with the District Attorney and law enforcement
policies.DefMal_Harm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Abuse definition includes harm or risk of harm; Neglect definition includes failure to protect from risk of harm
policies.DecentralizedReporting_Specify: County departments of human resources and local law enforcement agencies accept reports of suspected child abuse or neglect
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: Youth may request reentry if they are living in a situation where there is identifiable risk of harm that would typically result in the provision of child welfare services if they were under age 19; Youth's reentry may be authorized through the Department of Human Resource's resumption of legal custody if the case remained open on the court's administrative docket or it may be authorized through completion of an Agreement for Foster Care
policies.AltResp_EligibilityRiskOtherSpec: Family conditions or circumstances that, if left unchanged, can cause child abuse or neglect
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: Child at risk of maltreatment and the conditions or circumstances described do not constitute a child abuse or neglect allegation; Children who would be considered abused/neglected except for the fact that the person allegedly responsible is under age 14; Children for whom school personnel have reported concerns other than school attendance that indicate there may be a risk of maltreatment
policies.AltResp_ServiceReferralOtherSpec: The provision of on-going services is voluntary unless a safety threat exists or services have been court ordered. When the Child Protective Services (CPS) Prevention assessment reveals the children are safe, no significant risks have been identified, and the parents or primary caregivers have protective capacities sufficient to protect the children, the provision of on-going services is not necessary.
policies.InvestReq_PerpInterviewCase_Spec: Required unless the person is being criminally investigated, and law enforcement, the District Attorney's office or the defense attorney does not authorize the interview
